unnormalised: The blaring Punjabi beats spilled out onto Linking Road, a familiar soundtrack to Mumbai evenings. But tonight, it wasn’t coming from a wedding procession or a roadside chai stall. It was emanating from "Iron Temple," the newest gym to muscle its way onto the scene. This wasn’t your grandpa’s akhada, where you wrestled in the mud. This was urban gym culture, Mumbai style.
normalised: The blaring Punjabi beats spilled out onto Linking Road, a familiar soundtrack to Mumbai evenings. But tonight, it wasn’t coming from a wedding procession or a roadside chai stall. It was emanating from "Iron Temple," the newest gym to muscle its way onto the scene. This wasn’t your grandpa’s akhada, where you wrestled in the mud. This was urban gym culture, Mumbai style.

unnormalised: I remember my first time walking in. It was intimidating. Perfectly sculpted bodies, branded activewear that probably cost more than my monthly rent, and the constant clang of weights that sounded like a construction site. I, in my faded college tee and worn-out sneakers, felt decidedly out of place. But then I saw Priya aunty, all of 5’2”, deadlifting like a champion. She’d started coming after her daughters insisted it would help with her knee pain. That's when I understood.
normalised: I remember my first time walking in. It was intimidating. Perfectly sculpted bodies, branded activewear that probably cost more than my monthly rent, and the constant clang of weights that sounded like a construction site. I, in my faded college tee and worn-out sneakers, felt decidedly out of place. But then I saw Priya aunty, all of five feet two inches, deadlifting like a champion. She’d started coming after her daughters insisted it would help with her knee pain. That's when I understood.

unnormalised: This wasn’t just about sculpted abs and Instagram stories. It was about community. It was about pushing your limits, regardless of age or background. Iron Temple, like many urban gyms sprouting up across India, from Bangalore to Delhi, was offering something more than just treadmills and dumbbells. It was offering transformation.
normalised: This wasn’t just about sculpted abs and Instagram stories. It was about community. It was about pushing your limits, regardless of age or background. Iron Temple, like many urban gyms sprouting up across India, from Bangalore to Delhi, was offering something more than just treadmills and dumbbells. It was offering transformation.

unnormalised: I spotted Rohan, a former student from my coaching centre, prepping for a powerlifting competition. He used to be obsessed with IIT-JEE. Now, his obsession was the perfect form. His dedication reminded me of Rocky from 'Jo Jeeta Wohi Sikandar', just a different kind of race.
normalised: I spotted Rohan, a former student from my coaching centre, prepping for a powerlifting competition. He used to be obsessed with I I T-J E E. Now, his obsession was the perfect form. His dedication reminded me of Rocky from 'Jo Jeeta Wohi Sikandar', just a different kind of race.

unnormalised: The trainers, many certified by institutions like Gold’s Gym University, were patient and encouraging. They helped me design a workout plan, tailored to my needs and abilities (or rather, lack thereof!). They even explained the nutritional value of my beloved aloo paratha (in moderation, of course).
normalised: The trainers, many certified by institutions like Gold’s Gym University, were patient and encouraging. They helped me design a workout plan, tailored to my needs and abilities (or rather, lack thereof!). They even explained the nutritional value of my beloved aloo paratha (in moderation, of course).

unnormalised: It’s been 6 months now, and I can confidently say that urban gym culture has changed me. I’m stronger, healthier, and surprisingly, more confident. And while I still eye those Rs. 5000 leggings with envy, I’m focusing on lifting those kgs and celebrating every milestone, however small. The beats, the clang, the sweat – it’s all part of my urban rhythm now. Maybe I'll even attempt a deadlift like Priya aunty, someday.
normalised: It’s been six months now, and I can confidently say that urban gym culture has changed me. I’m stronger, healthier, and surprisingly, more confident. And while I still eye those rupee five thousand leggings with envy, I’m focusing on lifting those kilograms and celebrating every milestone, however small. The beats, the clang, the sweat – it’s all part of my urban rhythm now. Maybe I'll even attempt a deadlift like Priya aunty, someday.
